Research the project structure and scaffolding for a UXP plugin for Adobe Premiere Pro. Focus on:
1. What is the recommended folder structure for a UXP Premiere Pro plugin?
2. What does the manifest.json file need to contain?
3. What are the entry point files and how are they structured?
4. What build tools/bundlers are commonly used (webpack, vite, etc.)?
5. How do you set up a development environment with hot reloading?
6. What UI frameworks can be used (React, vanilla JS, Spectrum Web Components)?

Provide a detailed scaffolding outline for the project structure. This is research only - do not write code.

Links: [{"title":"Building your first UXP plugin","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/plugins/"},{"title":"Guides - Photoshop UXP Plugins","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2021/guides/ps_basics/"},{"title":"Folder Structure","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/xd/uxp/develop/plugin-development/plugin-structure/folder-structure/"},{"title":"Creating a Plugin with the UXP Developer Tool","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2021/guides/udt-walkthrough/"},{"title":"Adobe","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2021/guides/uxp-developer-tool/"},{"title":"Adobe UXP: Things you need to know! #3 UXP Developer Tool | Davide Barranca — Photoshop, etc.","url":"https://www.davidebarranca.com/development/Adobe-UXP-things-you-need-to-know-3-UXP-developer-tool.html"},{"title":"UXP Developer Tool (UDT) Walkthrough guide","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/guides/devtool/udt-walkthrough/"},{"title":"Get started - UXP plugin","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/indesign/uxp/plugins/getting-started/"},{"title":"File operations","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/indesign/uxp/resources/recipes/file-operation/"},{"title":"Packaging Your Plugin","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/guides/distribution/packaging-your-plugin/"}]

Here's what I found about Adobe UXP plugin folder structure and project scaffolding:

## Adobe UXP Plugin Folder Structure & Scaffolding

### Using the UXP Developer Tool (UDT)

The recommended approach is to download the UXP Developer Tool. You can use that tool to create a plugin folder containing basic scaffolding for HTML, JavaScript, and other required files.(no content)The UXP Developer Tool will create a new folder named after the Plugin ID in the desired location. The folder will contain the essential files needed for your plugin.

### Minimum Required Files

Within the parent folder, you'll need at minimum two files with exact names. The manifest.json and main.js files stored in your plugin's parent directory are the bare minimum requirement for your plugin to work, but it's possible to have more JavaScript files if you want.

**Key files:**
- **manifest.json** - This file is where you include facts about your plugin, such as its name, the menu item(s) it adds, and so on.
- **main.js** (or index.js) - This file contains your JavaScript code that implements the logic for your plugin.

### Template Options

You can select between two different templates: the ps-starter is the vanilla JavaScript one and then you have a React-based one.(no content)When saving plugin files, the Developer Tool will display a message saying you need to run extra commands from the terminal. This is not true for simple JavaScript-only plugins, only for React-based ones.

### Creating a Plugin

You can host as many plugins as you want in the UXP Developer Tool. You can either create the plugin folder structure and files from scratch and click the blue Add Plugin button in the Tool, or you can click the Create Plugin button.(no content)When you distribute your plugin, you'll need to obtain a plugin ID from the Adobe Developer Console. For testing, though, just invent an ID like 'com.yourname.pluginname'.

### File System Access

UXP does not allow arbitrary access to the local filesystem; for any file outside of your plugin's home folder, data folder, or temp folder, you must ask the user for access by presenting a built-in UXP dialog.(no content)For sandbox locations, you can use plugin:/, plugin-data:/ and plugin-temp:/. For other locations, use file:/.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here are the search results for Adobe UXP Premiere Pro plugin development official documentation:

## Official Documentation

The official Adobe UXP documentation for Premiere Pro plugin development is available at **[developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/)**

### Key Resources:

**Main Documentation Portal:**
Premiere adds its own APIs on top of the base UXP functionality, and the website provides documentation for both APIs.

**Version Requirements:**
UXP is the current extensibility standard for Adobe Creative Cloud applications, supported by a constantly growing set of applications, including Premiere (version 25.6), Photoshop, and InDesign.(no content)The UXP Developer Tool (UDT) simplifies the process of creating, loading, managing, and debugging plugins for Adobe's UXP-powered applications. UXP plugins are supported in Premiere v25.6 and later since UDT v2.2.

**Getting Started:**
To get started, ensure you have Premiere v25.6 installed. You will also need the latest build, v2.2.1, of the UXP Developer Tools (UDT) to load, debug, and package your plugins. You can download the UDT through Creative Cloud Desktop.

**Development Prerequisites:**
Developing in UXP requires some basic knowledge of Web technologies, such as JavaScript, HTML, and CSS.

**Documentation Coverage:**
- Learn the essentials, set up your development environment, and understand the technical stack. Step-by-step tutorials for creating panels, commands, and modal dialogs.
- Access sequences, tracks, clips, markers, project items, and application settings.
- Adobe's design system components for building plugin interfaces.

**API Differences from ExtendScript:**
An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, meaning they blocked the Premiere UI while they were executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous, and does not block the UI thread.

**Sample Code:**
The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available here: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/. Sample projects are available on GitHub at [AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here are the official requirements for the UXP Premiere Pro manifest.json structure:

## Overview

Each UXP plugin must have one manifest.json file that the host application uses to load and manage the plugin. In addition to core metadata such as the plugin's name, version, icons, and entry points, the manifest specifies permissions.(no content)The manifest also includes compatibility details and other definitions that shape how the plugin integrates with the host environment. Most importantly, it contains your plugin ID, which uniquely identifies your plugin when it's installed in the host application.

## Key Requirements

### Manifest Version
The manifest includes a field that indicates the version of the manifest schema. Premiere supports version "5".

### Plugin ID
The plugin ID uniquely identifies a plugin and is used to disambiguate plugin contexts, storage, errors, etc. For plugins distributed through the plugin marketplace, the id has to match the one set in the Developer Distribution portal.

### Permissions
To ensure that plugins are secure, UXP requires that plugins declare the permissions they need to function. Permissions not explicitly declared will be denied by default.(no content)You should configure the most accurate permission for your use case because in the future Adobe will ask users to provide their consent based on it. For example, for file operations, you may find "fullAccess" to be the least restrictive, but a user may not be comfortable giving full access to their system unless absolutely necessary.

### Clipboard Permissions
The manifest enables the plugin to read and write to the clipboard. Options include: read (enables reading from clipboard), readAndWrite (enables reading from and writing to clipboard). Default value is undefined (no clipboard access).

### Host Definition
The host field is an object matching the HostDefinition format. This entry allows your plugin to specify which app your plugin can run on.(no content)During development, the field can contain an array of HostDefinitions, which is convenient during development of cross-compatible UXP plugins. However, during submission to the marketplace, only one HostDefinition is allowed.

### Entry Points
The entrypoints field is an array of objects matching the EntryPointDefinition format. These entries appear both in the Plugins menu in the native menubar and the plugin panel. Each entry point specifies a type, to create either a direct-action command or a panel show/hide command.

### Feature Flags
A set of feature flags can be used to enable or disable certain features of the plugin. These flags are used to gate features that are not yet ready for general availability.

### Hybrid Plugin Support
The manifest supports addon definitions for hybrid plugins. A UXP Hybrid plugin is a UXP plugin that can access the power of C++ native libraries. However, Premiere doesn't support hybrid plugins yet.

## Development vs. Publishing Requirements

Some fields are "Develop" required (required for the plugin to be loaded), while others are "Publish" required (required for plugins to be submitted in the Adobe Developer Console and published in the Plugin Manager).(no content)Icons are not required during development, but must be provided when distributing through the Plugin Marketplace.

For complete documentation, visit the official Adobe developer documentation at: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/plugins/concepts/manifest/


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on my search, here's what I found about Adobe UXP hot reload development, watch mode, and debugging:

## UXP Developer Tool Watch Mode & Hot Reload

The UXP Developer Tool has a great "watch" feature that automatically reloads your plugins when (almost) any of the files in your plugin folder change. But unless you enable this watch feature (by selecting Watch in the Actions column), nothing will change in Photoshop when you save files.(no content)The best thing about the UXP Developer Tool is that you can choose Watch from the Actions menu, and the tool will automatically reload your plugin whenever you've changed your JavaScript, HTML, or CSS files. You can also select Reload from the Actions menu whenever you want to manually reload your plugin.

## Debugging Options

There are two main ways to debug UXP plugins:

1. **UXP Developer Tool Debugger**: The simplest way, suitable for many plugins, is to use the UXP Developer Tool. After a plugin has been loaded in the Developer Tool, choose Debug from the Actions menu for the plugin (on the far right of the Developer Tool window).

2. **Chrome DevTools**: The other way, if you've loaded your plugin using the command-line tools, is to use Chrome DevTools, as follows: In a new Chrome window, navigate to chrome://inspect. Press Configure... next to Discover network targets checkbox, and add localhost:xxxx (where "xxxx" is the port you declared in your debug.json file). When the extension is loaded, it should show up with its ID on this page.(no content)The debugger (which resembles the Chrome debugger) allows you to look at the console log, and do the usual debugger things such as setting breakpoints, stepping into and out of functions, etc.

## CLI Tools

The UXP devtools CLI allows you to reload your currently running plugin instance with new changes (no app restart required), launch a rich DevTools environment for debugging your plugin, and view your plugin logs. UXP Devtools are available in form of CLI and Standalone application.

## Working with React/Webpack

When you use React, you very likely have Webpack running and Webpack is going to output the final product into a /dist folder with its own manifest. You can tell the UXP DevTool where to find that distribution manifest so it can manage the hot-reloading properly.(no content)If you add the manifest.json in the plugin folder, then you need to update the relative path to the plugin build folder (dist) by clicking the ••• button > "Options" > "Advanced" > "Plugin build folder". During development, it is recommended to build the plugin using yarn watch and load the manifest.json in the (plugin build) dist folder.

## Important Notes

Do not edit code in the debugger - it won't save. Edit code in your IDE text editor, such as VSCode.(no content)Admin privileges are required to use UDT. The UXP Developer Tool requires administrator-level privileges to run correctly.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here are the search results for Adobe UXP plugin webpack vite build tools bundler configuration:

## Overview

UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform) is the modern way to create plugins and scripts for Adobe Creative Cloud. It's powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers a curated selection of UI components and a more streamlined workflow for developers.

## Build Tools and Bundler Configuration

### When You Need a Bundler

If you're using the UXP Developer Tool, and using plain JavaScript instead of React, you probably don't need any of the following tools.(no content)If you keep things modular inside main.js, you can build a clean, scalable plugin without Webpack or Vite. That said, for large projects, a build step can help with minification and separating dev/prod configs.

### Important Limitation

UXP doesn't support module imports unless you're compiling everything down into a single script.(no content)Adobe's UXP runtime doesn't support imports, modules, or component files. Everything has to live inside one main.js.

### Using Webpack

When working with React, other frameworks, or bundlers like Webpack and Parcel, you'll need to understand how to effectively use them inside the developer tool.

There's a starter project available: **[webpack-uxp-starter](https://github.com/emptykid/webpack-uxp-starter)** - Build Adobe UXP plugin with Webpack + React + Typescript.

### Using Vite

As Native ESM is not supported in UXP runtime, which means the default output of Vite is not work in UXP. A plugin-legacy was added to build type="text/javascript" instead of module type.(no content)Sadly, there seems to be bugs in the plugin, which makes vite build --watch not work as expected. An isolated node-watch was added to watch files.

A Vite starter is available: **[vite-uxp-starter](https://github.com/emptykid/vite-uxp-starter)**

### UXP Developer Tool Setup for Bundlers

When using bundlers or frameworks, you'll typically have two manifest.json files. One will be in your plugin's source code directory, and the other will be in your plugin's distribution directory. You can load either one of these, but you need to be aware of the differences.(no content)Adding a plugin using the distribution manifest.json means that you're loading the plugin from the distribution folder entirely. If your plugin build steps involve removing and recreating the distribution folder, or cleaning all the files within the folder, your plugin may not reload correctly in the developer tool.(no content)When you use React you very likely have Webpack running and Webpack is going to output the final product into a /dist folder with its own manifest, so you can tell the UXP DevTool where to find that distribution manifest so the UXP can manage with the hot-reloading.(no content)If you're adding a plugin that uses a bundler or framework make sure you install its dependencies by running npm install or yarn install. The Developer Tool will not do this for you.

### Recommended Package Managers

npm is a "package manager" bundled with Node which helps manage your project's dependencies (i.e., other code and files that are needed to make your plugin work).(no content)yarn is a "better" package manager than npm for Node. Many people, including those developing Photoshop UXP tools, are using yarn instead of npm.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

content.content:
# UXP Premiere Pro Sample Repository Structure

## Project Organization

Based on the README, the repository contains a sample UXP plugin with the following structure:

```
uxp-premiere-pro-samples/
├── .github/
├── payloads/
├── sample-panels/
│   └── premiere-api/
│       └── html/
├── .gitignore
├── CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
├── COPYRIGHT
├── LICENSE
├── README.md
└── yarn.lock
```

## Key Directories

**sample-panels/premiere-api/html** — The primary development folder where developers work on the plugin. This directory contains the source files and requires running `npm i` to install dependencies.

**build-html** — The output destination created after running `npm run build`. This compiled directory contains the manifest.json file needed for plugin loading.

**assets** — Located within the premiere-api/html directory, this folder includes supporting files like "Premiere Pro's transcript JSON definition."

## Manifest File Location

The manifest.json file is generated at: `premiere-api/build-html/manifest.json`

This path is used when loading the plugin into the UXP Developer Tool by clicking "Add Plugin" and navigating to this manifest location.

## Build Dependencies

The project uses npm with TypeScript (72.2% of codebase), JavaScript (16.9%), HTML (10.2%), and CSS (0.7%).

Here are the search results for Adobe UXP Spectrum Web Components React UI framework plugin development:

## Overview

Spectrum UXP is an implementation of the Spectrum Web Components API and the Spectrum Design System.(no content)Spectrum Web Components are open-source Adobe Spectrum-styled Web Components, and UXP v7.0 introduces the support for Web Components and Spectrum Web Components (SWC).

## Using React with Spectrum UXP

React does not attach event listeners to elements that are Web Components. This is technically correct, as React can't know that a particular attribute is an event handler, but it does lead to surprising results that feel broken as event handlers aren't called correctly.(no content)The simplest fix is to add a ref to the component and attach event listeners. This results in a lot of unnecessary code, so Adobe built a simple wrapper component (WC) that takes care of the hard work. You'll see examples of this in their plugin samples where they wrap Spectrum UXP components with this component.

### Key React Quirks with Web Components

- Web Components do not support tags that are self-closing. As such, you must always have the full ending tag.
- Web Components in React use `class` instead of `className`.
- Boolean attributes like `checked` are not treated correctly by React - any value (even a string-coerced "false") is treated as true. Instead, the web expects `checked` to not be present at all if the checkbox should be unchecked.

## React Libraries and Starter Templates

The `react-uxp-spectrum` package aims to make development of UXP plugins using React a breeze and encapsulates all of the quirks and oddities that come with a web-component based library being used in React.(no content)Adobe provides a starter template to help create React-based UXP plugins using Spectrum Web Components (SWC), including setting up the project, integrating the SWC components, and mounting it over the host application like Photoshop.(no content)Photoshop and InDesign React-based SWC starter plugins have been available since UXP v7.3.

## SWC Component Versioning

The UXP-SWC components are delivered via wrappers over specific SWC versions. For example, @swc-uxp-wrappers/menu is locked and wrapped on version 0.16.9 of @spectrum-web-components/menu. For React framework, you need to use @swc-react/menu:0.16.9-react.3029 which is the react-wrapper closest to the SWC component version.(no content)With UXP v8.0.0, all the SWC components in UXP are locked to version 0.37.0.

## Alternative Boilerplates

The Adobe UXP team is moving away from the built-in Spectrum UXP to Spectrum Web Components. Since this move is recent and compatibility is pending, some boilerplates like Bolt UXP don't come set up for Spectrum integration by default.

## Benefits of Spectrum UXP Widgets

With Spectrum UXP widgets you don't have to worry about different color themes. The sp-heading element automatically becomes dark on lighter themes and light on darker themes, unlike regular HTML elements.(no content)Using a Spectrum UXP component in a UXP plugin is easy - there are no libraries or stylesheets to include.

content.content:
# Bolt UXP: Project Structure & Organization

## Overview
Bolt UXP is "a lightning-fast boilerplate for building Adobe UXP Plugins in Svelte, React, or Vue built on Vite + TypeScript + Sass."

## Supported Frameworks
The boilerplate offers three frontend options:
- **React** - Modern component-based framework
- **Svelte** - Compiler-based approach with minimal overhead
- **Vue** - Progressive framework with flexible architecture

Each framework has dedicated configuration files: `package.react.jsonc`, `package.svelte.jsonc`, and `package.vue.jsonc`.

## Project Structure

### Core Directories
- **`src/`** - Main UXP plugin code with TypeScript support
- **`src/api/`** - Global functions and app-specific APIs (Photoshop, InDesign, etc.)
- **`src/hybrid/`** - C++ hybrid plugin source files (optional)
- **`webview-ui/`** - Separate frontend context for webview UI (optional)
- **`public/`** - Static assets and public resources
- **`public-hybrid/`** - Compiled hybrid plugin binaries
- **`dist/`** - Build output for distribution

### Configuration Files
- **`uxp.config.ts`** - Central UXP plugin configuration
- **`vite.config.ts`** - Vite build tooling setup
- **`tsconfig.json`** - TypeScript configuration per framework

## Build & Development Features

The boilerplate emphasizes "lightning-fast hot reloading on changes" through built-in WebSocket systems that replace the less reliable file-watching approach in Adobe's Developer Tools.

**Key Build Outputs:**
- Development builds for debugging
- CCX packaging for distribution across different Adobe apps
- ZIP archives with sidecar assets via `copyZipAssets` configuration

## Architecture Highlights

Multi-context setup supports separating concerns between UXP backend logic and webview frontend UI, using Comlink for type-safe communication via `postMessage()` APIs.

# webpack-uxp-starter Project Structure Analysis

## Folder Structure
The repository contains:
- **src/** directory (primary source code location)
- Configuration files at root level
- Package management via yarn

## Build Configuration Approach
The project uses Webpack as its bundler, as evidenced by the presence of `webpack.config.js` at the root directory. This configuration file handles the transformation of React + TypeScript source code into Adobe UXP plugin format.

## Manifest Location
The `manifest.json` file is located at the repository root, which is the standard location for Adobe UXP plugin metadata and plugin configuration details.

## Available Build Scripts
According to the README, two primary yarn commands are available:

- **Development mode:** "yarn watch" enables continuous compilation during development
- **Production mode:** "yarn build" generates optimized output for distribution

The project also requires running "yarn install" initially to establish dependencies. TypeScript support is configured via `tsconfig.json`, and the tech stack combines JavaScript (65.5%), HTML (18.5%), and TypeScript (16.0%).

Links: [{"title":"Building your first UXP plugin","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/plugins/"},{"title":"GitHub - AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples"},{"title":"The Premiere UXP API","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/"},{"title":"GitHub - hyperbrew/bolt-uxp: A lightning-fast boilerplate for building Adobe UXP Plugins in Svelte, React, or Vue built on Vite + TypeScript + Sass","url":"https://github.com/hyperbrew/bolt-uxp"},{"title":"Get started - UXP plugin","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/plugins/getting-started/"},{"title":"UXP Manifest","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/plugins/concepts/manifest/"},{"title":"Adobe UXP: Things you need to know! #4 Commands, Panels and the manifest.json | Davide Barranca — Photoshop, etc.","url":"https://www.davidebarranca.com/development/adobe-uxp-things-you-need-to-know-4-commands-panels-manifest"},{"title":"uxp-premiere-pro-samples/README.md at main · AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples/blob/main/README.md"},{"title":"GitHub - AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro"},{"title":"Manifest File Structure - UXP Manifest","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/guides/uxp_guide/uxp-misc/manifest-v4/"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about UXP plugin file structure for Premiere Pro, focusing on entry points and the `index.html`/`index.js` files:

## UXP Plugin File Structure for Premiere Pro

### Entry Point Files

The manifest indicates the primary JavaScript or HTML file, relative to the plugin's installation directory. It supports HTML and JS files, such as `index.html` and `index.js`.(no content)If not specified, `main.js` is used as the default.

### Key Files in a UXP Plugin

Each UXP plugin must have one `manifest.json` file that the host application uses to load and manage the plugin. In addition to core metadata such as the plugin's name, version, icons, and entry points, the manifest specifies permissions, compatibility details, and other definitions that shape how the plugin integrates with the host environment.

### index.html
Open the `index.html` file in your code editor. This file contains the HTML code that defines the visual content of your plugin's panel.

### index.js
The implementation lives in the `index.js` file, and it uses the Premiere APIs to fetch the information. You can open the file and explore the code to see how it works.

### Building Plugins

For sample plugins, you open your console/terminal/command prompt into `sample-panels/premiere-api/html`. The plugin is now built in the `/build-html` directory.(no content)Navigate to the `premiere-api/build-html/manifest.json`, and click Open to load the plugin.

### Entry Points in Manifest

The `entrypoints` array defines the entrypoints that the plugin provides; currently, only Commands and Panels are supported.

### Alternative Build Approach (Bolt UXP)

When build is run with Bolt UXP, the webview first builds to a single `index.html` source, then copied into individual HTML files per panel (e.g., `main.html` and `settings.html`) file in the `public/webview-ui` directory which is then copied to dist.

### Requirements

Premiere Pro (v25.2) or later and UXP Developer Tool v2.1 are required (both can be installed from the Creative Cloud Desktop app).

Based on the search results, here's what I found about UXP plugin file structure for Premiere Pro, focusing on entry points and the `index.html`/`index.js` files:

## UXP Plugin File Structure for Premiere Pro

### Entry Point Files

The manifest indicates the primary JavaScript or HTML file, relative to the plugin's installation directory. It supports HTML and JS files, such as `index.html` and `index.js`.(no content)If not specified, `main.js` is used as the default.

### Key Files in a UXP Plugin

Each UXP plugin must have one `manifest.json` file that the host application uses to load and manage the plugin. In addition to core metadata such as the plugin's name, version, icons, and entry points, the manifest specifies permissions, compatibility details, and other definitions that shape how the plugin integrates with the host environment.

### index.html
Open the `index.html` file in your code editor. This file contains the HTML code that defines the visual content of your plugin's panel.

### index.js
The implementation lives in the `index.js` file, and it uses the Premiere APIs to fetch the information. You can open the file and explore the code to see how it works.

### Building Plugins

For sample plugins, you open your console/terminal/command prompt into `sample-panels/premiere-api/html`. The plugin is now built in the `/build-html` directory.(no content)Navigate to the `premiere-api/build-html/manifest.json`, and click Open to load the plugin.

### Entry Points in Manifest

The `entrypoints` array defines the entrypoints that the plugin provides; currently, only Commands and Panels are supported.

### Alternative Build Approach (Bolt UXP)

When build is run with Bolt UXP, the webview first builds to a single `index.html` source, then copied into individual HTML files per panel (e.g., `main.html` and `settings.html`) file in the `public/webview-ui` directory which is then copied to dist.

content.text:
Based on my research, I now have comprehensive information to provide a detailed scaffolding outline for a UXP Premiere Pro plugin. Let me compile the findings.

---

# UXP Premiere Pro Plugin: Project Structure and Scaffolding Research

## 1. Recommended Folder Structure

Based on official Adobe documentation and community best practices, here is the recommended folder structure:

### Minimal Plugin Structure (Vanilla JavaScript)
```
my-premiere-plugin/
├── manifest.json          # Required: Plugin metadata and configuration
├── index.html             # Main entry point (HTML-based panel)
├── index.js               # JavaScript logic
├── styles.css             # Optional: Custom styles
└── icons/                 # Plugin icons (required for distribution)
    ├── icon-24.png
    ├── icon-48.png
    └── icon-96.png
```

### Full Project Structure (With Build Tools)
```
my-premiere-plugin/
├── src/                        # Source code
│   ├── index.html              # Main HTML entry
│   ├── index.js                # Main JavaScript entry
│   ├── index.ts                # TypeScript source (if using TS)
│   ├── components/             # UI components
│   ├── api/                    # Premiere Pro API wrappers
│   └── styles/                 # CSS/SCSS files
├── dist/                       # Build output (generated)
│   ├── manifest.json           # Copied/generated manifest
│   ├── index.html
│   └── index.js
├── public/                     # Static assets
│   └── icons/
├── manifest.json               # Source manifest
├── package.json                # Node dependencies
├── webpack.config.js           # Or vite.config.ts
├── tsconfig.json               # If using TypeScript
└── README.md
```

---

## 2. Manifest.json Structure

Premiere Pro supports **manifest version 5**. Here is the complete structure:

### Required Fields
```json
{
  "manifestVersion": 5,
  "id": "com.yourcompany.pluginname",
  "name": "My Premiere Plugin",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "main": "index.html",
  "host": {
    "app": "premierepro",
    "minVersion": "25.6.0"
  },
  "entrypoints": [
    {
      "type": "panel",
      "id": "mainPanel",
      "label": { "default": "My Panel" }
    }
  ]
}
```

### Complete Manifest with All Options
```json
{
  "manifestVersion": 5,
  "id": "com.yourcompany.pluginname",
  "name": "My Premiere Pro Plugin",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "A description of your plugin",
  "main": "index.html",
  
  "host": {
    "app": "premierepro",
    "minVersion": "25.6.0"
  },
  
  "entrypoints": [
    {
      "type": "panel",
      "id": "mainPanel",
      "label": { "default": "Main Panel" },
      "minimumSize": { "width": 230, "height": 200 },
      "maximumSize": { "width": 2000, "height": 2000 },
      "preferredDockedSize": { "width": 230, "height": 300 },
      "preferredFloatingSize": { "width": 400, "height": 500 }
    },
    {
      "type": "command",
      "id": "myCommand",
      "label": { "default": "Run My Command" }
    }
  ],
  
  "icons": [
    { "width": 24, "height": 24, "path": "icons/icon-24.png", "scale": [1, 2] },
    { "width": 48, "height": 48, "path": "icons/icon-48.png", "scale": [1, 2] }
  ],
  
  "requiredPermissions": {
    "localFileSystem": "fullAccess",
    "clipboard": "readAndWrite",
    "network": {
      "domains": ["https://api.example.com"]
    },
    "launchProcess": {
      "schemes": ["https", "mailto"],
      "extensions": [".pdf"]
    },
    "allowCodeGenerationFromStrings": true
  }
}
```

### Key Manifest Fields Explained
| Field | Required | Description |
|-------|----------|-------------|
| `manifestVersion` | Yes | Must be `5` for Premiere Pro |
| `id` | Yes | Unique plugin identifier (e.g., `com.company.plugin`) |
| `name` | Yes | Display name of the plugin |
| `version` | Yes | Semantic version (e.g., `1.0.0`) |
| `main` | Yes | Entry point file (`index.html` or `index.js`) |
| `host` | Yes | Target application (`premierepro`) and minimum version |
| `entrypoints` | Yes | Array of panels and commands |
| `icons` | Publish | Required for marketplace distribution |
| `requiredPermissions` | No | Security permissions for file, network, clipboard access |

---

## 3. Entry Point Files and Structure

### HTML Entry Point (index.html)
```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
</head>
<body>
  <sp-heading>My Plugin</sp-heading>
  <sp-button id="actionBtn">Run Action</sp-button>
  <script src="index.js"></script>
</body>
</html>
```

### JavaScript Entry Point (index.js)
```javascript
const { entrypoints } = require("uxp");
const ppro = require("ppro");  // Premiere Pro API

// Setup entry points
entrypoints.setup({
  panels: {
    mainPanel: {
      show() {
        // Called when panel is shown
      },
      hide() {
        // Called when panel is hidden
      },
      create() {
        // Called when panel is created
      },
      destroy() {
        // Called when panel is destroyed
      }
    }
  },
  commands: {
    myCommand: {
      run() {
        // Command execution logic
      }
    }
  }
});

// Event listeners
document.getElementById("actionBtn").addEventListener("click", async () => {
  const project = await ppro.Project.getActiveProject();
  // Work with the project
});
```

### Entry Point Types
- **Panel**: Creates a dockable UI panel (type: `"panel"`)
- **Command**: Creates a menu command (type: `"command"`)

---

## 4. Build Tools and Bundlers

### Important Limitation
UXP does not support ES modules natively. All code must be bundled into a single file.

### Option 1: No Bundler (Simple Plugins)
- For vanilla JavaScript plugins without frameworks
- Keep all code in a single `main.js` or `index.js`
- No build step required

### Option 2: Webpack
- Recommended for React + TypeScript projects
- Community starter: [webpack-uxp-starter](https://github.com/emptykid/webpack-uxp-starter)

**package.json scripts:**
```json
{
  "scripts": {
    "watch": "webpack --watch --mode development",
    "build": "webpack --mode production"
  }
}
```

### Option 3: Vite
- Community starter: [vite-uxp-starter](https://github.com/emptykid/vite-uxp-starter)
- Requires `@vitejs/plugin-legacy` because UXP does not support ES modules
- Known issue: `vite build --watch` may have bugs; use separate file watcher

### Option 4: Bolt UXP (Recommended for Modern Development)
- Repository: [hyperbrew/bolt-uxp](https://github.com/hyperbrew/bolt-uxp)
- Supports **React**, **Svelte**, and **Vue**
- Built on Vite + TypeScript + Sass
- Features built-in hot reloading via WebSocket (more reliable than file watching)
- Supports multi-app plugins (Photoshop, InDesign, Premiere Pro)

**Bolt UXP Structure:**
```
bolt-uxp-project/
├── src/                    # UXP plugin code
│   └── api/                # App-specific APIs
├── webview-ui/             # Frontend (React/Svelte/Vue)
├── public/                 # Static assets
├── dist/                   # Build output
├── uxp.config.ts           # UXP configuration
├── vite.config.ts          # Vite configuration
└── package.json
```

---

## 5. Development Environment with Hot Reloading

### UXP Developer Tool (UDT)
- **Required version**: v2.2.1 or later for Premiere Pro support
- Download via Creative Cloud Desktop
- Requires **administrator privileges**

### Setup Steps
1. Install Premiere Pro v25.6 or later
2. Install UXP Developer Tool v2.2.1+
3. Launch UDT and click "Add Plugin"
4. Navigate to your `manifest.json` location
5. Enable "Watch" mode for automatic reloading

### Watch Mode
- In UDT, select "Watch" from the Actions menu for your plugin
- Changes to `.js`, `.html`, `.css` files trigger automatic reload
- For bundled projects, point UDT to the `dist/` folder manifest

### Debugging
1. In UDT, select "Debug" from Actions menu
2. Opens Chrome DevTools-like debugger
3. Features: Console, breakpoints, step-through, network inspection

### CLI Alternative
- Repository: [adobe-uxp/devtools-cli](https://github.com/adobe-uxp/devtools-cli)
- Provides command-line plugin loading and debugging
- Chrome DevTools integration via `chrome://inspect`

### For Bundled Projects (Webpack/Vite)
```bash
# Terminal 1: Run bundler in watch mode
npm run watch

# Terminal 2: UDT loads from dist/ folder
# Enable Watch in UDT Actions menu
```

---

## 6. UI Frameworks

### Option 1: Vanilla JavaScript + Spectrum UXP
- No build step required
- Uses built-in Spectrum UXP components (prefixed with `sp-`)
- Automatic dark/light theme support

**Example:**
```html
<sp-heading>Title</sp-heading>
<sp-button variant="primary">Click Me</sp-button>
<sp-textfield placeholder="Enter text"></sp-textfield>
<sp-slider min="0" max="100"></sp-slider>
```

### Option 2: Spectrum Web Components (SWC)
- Modern, open-source Spectrum components
- UXP v7.0+ supports Web Components
- SWC components locked to version 0.37.0 in UXP v8.0.0
- Requires wrapper packages for React integration

### Option 3: React
- Requires bundler (Webpack or Vite)
- Use `@swc-react/*` packages for Spectrum components
- Wrapper needed for Web Component event handling

**React Quirks with Web Components:**
- Must use `class` instead of `className`
- Cannot use self-closing tags
- Boolean attributes need special handling
- Use wrapper component or `react-uxp-spectrum` package

**React starter templates:**
- Adobe React template via UDT "Create Plugin"
- [hyperbrew/bolt-uxp](https://github.com/hyperbrew/bolt-uxp)
- [xWermuth/adobe.uxp.react.typescript.starter](https://github.com/xWermuth/adobe.uxp.react.typescript.starter)

### Option 4: Svelte / Vue
- Supported via [Bolt UXP](https://github.com/hyperbrew/bolt-uxp)
- Good compatibility with Web Components

---

## Complete Scaffolding Outline

### Recommended Modern Project Structure (React + TypeScript + Vite)

```
my-premiere-uxp-plugin/
├── src/
│   ├── index.html                  # Main panel HTML
│   ├── index.tsx                   # React entry point
│   ├── App.tsx                     # Main React component
│   ├── components/
│   │   ├── Panel.tsx               # Panel UI component
│   │   └── Controls.tsx            # Control components
│   ├── hooks/
│   │   └── usePremiereApi.ts       # Custom hooks for Premiere API
│   ├── api/
│   │   ├── premiere.ts             # Premiere Pro API wrapper
│   │   └── entrypoints.ts          # UXP entrypoint setup
│   ├── styles/
│   │   └── main.scss               # Global styles
│   └── types/
│       └── uxp.d.ts                # UXP type declarations
├── public/
│   └── icons/
│       ├── icon-24.png
│       ├── icon-48.png
│       └── icon-96.png
├── dist/                           # Build output (git-ignored)
│   ├── manifest.json
│   ├── index.html
│   ├── index.js
│   └── icons/
├── manifest.json                   # Source manifest
├── package.json
├── vite.config.ts
├── tsconfig.json
├── .gitignore
└── README.md
```

### Minimal Vanilla JS Structure
```
my-simple-plugin/
├── manifest.json
├── index.html
├── index.js
├── styles.css
└── icons/
    └── icon.png
```

---

## Key Requirements Summary

| Requirement | Value |
|-------------|-------|
| Premiere Pro Version | 25.6 or later |
| UXP Developer Tool | v2.2.1 or later |
| Manifest Version | 5 |
| Host App ID | `premierepro` |
| Entry Point Types | `panel`, `command` |
| API Style | Asynchronous (unlike ExtendScript) |

---

- [UXP Manifest for Premiere Pro](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/plugins/concepts/manifest/)
